review_title: Lab Support Tech I/Lab Support Tech II Review
job_title: Clinical Laboratory Support Technician II in Fond du Lac, WI
pros:
Working as a Lab Assistant at St. Agnes Hospital is a great opportunity for college students who want to better understand many of the roles in health care. I am fortunate to collaborate with doctors, nurses, PA’s, NP’s, respiratory therapists, ultrasound techs, etc. due to drawing blood in many departments. I often draw blood in the ER, ICU, Cath Lab, Day Surgery, occasionally the OR, GI Lab, Women and Infants, the hospital floors, and nursing homes. Luckily, if you don’t like working second or third shift, employees can work in the Outpatient Lab, which operates during normal business hours. 

This job is truly amazing and if I had to go back in time to when I was looking for jobs, I would absolutely choose this career all over again. Like all jobs, there are pros and cons. In my case, all of the pros out way the cons, by far.
cons:
Working as a Phlebotomist or a Lab Assistant has many benefits, however, there are several downsides. Here are a few:
- Our department has a force-to-work policy, meaning that if you have the least amount of volunteered hours, you will be forced to work shifts from employees who are on leave of absences, people who quit, etc. Missing a forced shift will be an occurrence. 
- The work schedule only comes out two weeks in advance due to staffing shortages, and management is not flexible with rearranging the schedule once it is posted.
- It’s really difficult to get seniority PTO approved.

All-in-all, this position is an excellent way to immerse yourself into the healthcare setting, whether your employment is short term, or if you are in it for the long haul.

job_title: Executive Recruiter in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Strong mission and values
- Decent benefits - health, dental, vision, 403b
- PTO - 24 days annually, incudes vacation, sick, and holidays
cons:
- Difficult to move up in the corporate space unless located in the St. Louis Area
- As a not for profit organization, they run very lean. You may be picking up the slack of others permanently when they leave the organization. With the COVID furloughs and layoffs in 2020, team members were not replaced while those still employed were doing the job of 2-3 people with no pay increases. 
- As a WFH employee, work life balance is non-existent. 
- Resources are limited to do your job efficiently. 
- Pay is typically lower than their competitors, especially within the clinical space
- Increases only happen in May, and are between 2-3% of your annual salary. 
- Bonuses are only available to employees at the VP level or above
- Ideas and improvements are listened to by leadership, but impactful change is rarely made.
- Within one year (2021), over 70% of the recruitment team left the organization. Those left were given little to no support by senior leadership. If that's not a red flag for anyone looking at joining this organization, I don't know what is.

review_title: The best large healthcare system to work with
job_title: Buyer in Madison, WI
pros: SSM was my employer in a few capacities over ten years, and I was a Buyer for the last five years or so. Benefits are equitable and employees qualify for adjusted benefit and prescription costs based on income, which I feel is a huge positive. My management while in the Buying role was excellent. Respectful and engaged, appreciative and I was never needlessly micromanaged. The other employees at my location were generally friendly and knowledgeable in their areas. I worked in Durable Medical Equipment division and many employees are niche experts. My immediate coworker was extremely hard working, knowledgeable, kind and fun. No high drama either at this company. After taking a position in a different state at another very large healthcare system, I miss SAM'S Respect for employees, great and equitable benefits, better wages, more attentive management. No medical system is perfect but they were significantly more organized and treated their employees very well when compared with my current employer who is a top 2 nationally ranked healthcare system. If SSM expanded into this state, I would immediately go back with them for many reasons. I didn't realize how great they were until I had another medical system for comparison. Also, Human Resources and Upper Management were very supportive of myself and other employees during family emergencies or personal health emergencies. I know this probably sounds too good to be true but this company's support helped me get through some difficult parts of my life.
cons: Nothing major in my honest opinion. The only area where they did not surpass other major medical systems was in some retirement benefits and some fringe benefits other healthcare systems offer that SSM does not as far as I am aware. Like discounts on club, gym, water park vacation and children activity destinations. But these are extra perks, and they do offer some, just not as many as some other systems.

I think in 3 years I have maybe gotten a total of 30 cents. Which is ridiculous for the experience gained. This company frequently puts employees in violent and threatening situations to just keep the patient for the pay out. They treat you as just bodies that they use to not get in trouble by state for line of sight precaution people, etc. Then when you get hurt and you have to go on light duty, they don't pay for your first 3 days of necessary off work, so they take it out of your PTO not EMTO, even when it is clearly a work related injury. I feel like the older nurses do not care for my safety and frequently walk away from threatening situations. Some of my shift supervisors have clearly never managed people and treat employees like they are an annoyance that she would rather not deal with, never employs any empathy. Will never work for this company again. I thought I could stay and move into a higher position with better pay but that is not a possibility.

job_title: Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: This organization has two components....the patient care side is full of dedicated employees who are motivated by the Mission Statement and provide good quality care to patients.  SSM Health is very employee centric which is both good and bad, they pay well and have decent benefits.
cons:
The other component consists of the administrative and back office functions.  There is something fundamentally wrong with leadership. This organization is extremely top heavy...not something I expected for a "not-for-profit" system..   Too many leaders who are not willing to make a decision because they might be held accountable even though leaders and managers are not held accountable there. .

HR rules with an iron fist and makes decisions without regard to cost or policy as long as it makes the employees happy....typically they take the path of least resistance and have little to no regard for what is best for the business. 

Finance, which is typically one of the stronger departments in any organization, is saddled with poor leadership....leaders who avoid confrontation, don't back their employees back and who tell staff members to leave if they don't like it there...they have no skills in motivating or engaging employees and no interest in learning how.

review_title: They say they are all about "the mission", but sadly, it's all about the money.
job_title: Care Team Coordinator in Clayton, MO
pros:
benefits
clean
lots of different clinical departments
shift options
cafeteria
central location decent parking
some great doctors
some good nurses there
good training department
cons:
They talk about the nurses as if they are nuns, praising their supposed willingness to angels of mercy with no needs of their own.
The reality is that they expect you to work sometimes dangerously under-staffed and not terribly well paid.
Lack of upper management support when something goes really wrong.
They will punish you for a WC injury unless you do your regular job despite orders against it and without complaining, and pretend they have not asked you to do so, but that you insist.
They are terrified of firing a minority staff person, so they insult the excellent minority staff by forcing them and non-minorities to work with them indefinitely, even if their performance is AWFUL or even dangerous. If you're managing this employee, it's hands-off or out YOU go.

job_title: Physician in Saint Louis, MO
pros:

cons:
Physicians don't get a say in important decisions that affect practice, equipment purchased,  hiring staff. I guess some physicians do, but I sure don't get listened to, and I do speak up. SSM is cheap about otherwise lower paid staff which really stretches that staff.  Or we don't have the support we need for the "extended hours" we are asked to have.  Physicians could do more if the office was better staffed.  I also get the feeling that I am completely disposable: that even though my patients and staff would miss me, administration couldn't care less if I left. I feel like a RVU-generator.

In addition, I have been disappointed in lack of faithfulness to mission. They call themselves Catholic, but a lot of things go on that are not in line with Catholic teaching.

pros: Low volume ED, only 3 shifts a week. No homeless patient's patient base is moderate income families. Also patient's from small towns to south. cons:
Below market hourly wages.  Lack of support from all levels of management.  Patient satisfaction is considered more important than patient outcomes.  Physicians give drug seekers narcotics to improve their Press Ganey scores so this increases the repeat visits of this population.
East Healthplex is very dysfunctional I would not recommend working at that location.
Mustang and North Healthplex are both great work environments.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I really like the CNO Patti Kelly, when meeting with her she has a real concern for her nurses and then I am also a big fan of the progress SLUH has made and the more progression it will be making with the new hospital
cons: There is a tremendous turnover rate here and when I started I was working with an entirely different staff. The relationships you make are really just temporary and I wanted to go somewhere they have a better turnover rate and the staff stays in one place longer. I also have had a lot of push back with staff and only doing an ok job with what they are appointed and sometimes they just don't even do what is expected with their job. I wanted to go somewhere where there would be a place where I can be in charge of the total patient care. I was also a weekday night nurses and I would be working a weekend shift almost every week.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The pay is decent and if you get into the right group you'll have additional extras like wearing jeans on Fridays or choosing how you want to work your work week.
cons:
There is no leadership by example anymore.   They just tell you what they want you to do but they do not do the same.  Nor do they live out our mission and values like the previous leaders did.  The only people living out the mission and values are those with direct patient care.  
I haven't seen leaders held accountable for several years now.   It depends on where you work, you could get extras like wearing jeans on Fridays or you can choose how you want to work out your work week.  For example, 4 ten hour days, 4 nine hour days and a half-day, or the regular 5 eight hour days.  But if you don't get into a group like these, you just watch from the sidelines.  It's pitiful.  And it's all one organization but the days of treating every one the same are clearly over.

review_title: No raises for employees the past two years, unless you're management or corporate.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Fellow employees (non managerial) are there because they care for kids.  Great group of people to work with!  Decent benefits if you are full time despite recent major cuts.
cons: Management (& there are so many of them!)  You cannot transfer after 6months from your department if you choose and are hired in another department.  You're manager can deny the transfer.  Managers can issue "levels" or "write ups" with no previous warnings (verbal or written) disqualifying you from your meager yearly raise ( that has been removed past 2 yrs regardless due to 'cutbacks')  Mandatory time off when census is low regardless of the fact it has no bearing on your department.  No checks and balances on certain areas and overdone in others.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Janesville, WI
pros: A new hospital opened in 2012, adjacent to clinic. Many co workers are the best thing about this place. The environment is new and clean. All patient rooms are private.
cons: Revolving door of management and staff. Staff to patient ratio is low. Leadership has their heads in the sand as to why employee satisfaction scores are so low. A cesspool of gossip and rumors, like living in a soap opera. If patient safety issues are reported, you're likely to be fired, even though there is supposed to be a "non-punitive" culture. Because of this, employees are afraid to speak up and most are looking for other jobs, as am I. A stressful environment for sure. Wages are low in comparison to other hospitals and insurance benefits are higher than the competition. Most of the best care givers have gone elsewhere because they either couldn't stand the environment of distrust, deception and lies, or they were run off by inexperienced managers who were fearful of losing their own jobs. Worst place I've ever worked.

job_title: Nurse in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Location, patient level employees care and are good
cons: Management is extremely poor. They not only have no vision for the future but don't seem to know how to even manage a health system. Nursing to patient ratios are unsafe. There is never enough equipment. The turn over is so high that the most senior nurses have less than  2 years experience. The worse is that their billing practices are questionable, they contract out all sorts of jobs so a patient t will receive multiple bills from multiple specialties. Keeping g I  like d those specialties aren't even related to SSM so they are much more aggressive with collecting debt. This system states it's a Catholic organization but I will tell you that is just not true. They are only Catholic from the outside meaning advertisements and commercials. Nothing Christian about this place.

job_title: Claims Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: It allows me to pay my bills.
cons: Starting in 2020, employees will have to use their vacation time to pay for holidays.  For example, the business will be closed for the 4th of July, and I will have to use my vacation time to cover it.  If I don't have enough vacation time set aside to cover it, I will get an occurrence (a bad mark).  This is unethical, immoral, and downright offensive.  I have to figure out when I'm going to be sick, when my kids will be sick, and make sure I have enough days saved up to cover holidays, since we "earn" our vacation days as we work.  I have never had a company stoop this low, and I am looking for another job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: My direct supervisor is a very fair, genuine and kind man who always treats me with respect. I’ve learned a lot from him. He is the type of supervisor SSM should want for all their employees.
cons:
Non-collaborative environment. I can’t tell you how many emails I send out to other team members that have never responded. If your program requires collaboration with other departments you may as well forget it. 
I’ve been here three years with no “fun” department lunches or collaboration as a team. Quarterly team meetings are routinely canceled. 
Benefits keep getting worse. Major reduction in PTO. No more EMTO for sick time. Apparently we encourage people to come to work and share their germs. Completely behind the times in what employees want and need in an employer. I foresee ongoing employee turnover.

review_title: Worst experience in many years of nursing.

job_title: Home Health Nurse in Saint Louis, MO
pros:

cons:
This is specifically about the home health sector of SSM.  This organization leaves much to be desired.  One would expect with such a trusted name like SSM in the community having such an influence over health care in the Saint Louis region, that the company would show more of a concern over how their home health sector is ran, but this has proven to not be true.

The Saint Louis branch is on the verge of crumbling.

review_title: I was lied to time and time again by management
job_title: IT Trainer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: hard working staff; pleasant (most of them) at working level
cons: Management in my department was based in St. Louis.  The ended up hiring a inept manager in OKC.  15 of us started out as "temps" and were promised work (without benefits) until Dec. 23rd.  When asked in meetings if we would be kept until then, they positively said "Yes".  They ended up cutting us short (right before Christmas with children to feed at home) and then after 8 months of hard work, (and after telling us there would be "permanent positions" for us), they made us go through a lengthy and cumbersome interview process.  After it was all said and done, they ended up keeping a few and hiring all brand new employees to fill the rest of our positions.  Don't believe the Catholic Hype!

job_title: Clinical Lab Scientist in Madison, WI
pros: There is a chance to grow your skills professionally as you put in your time.

Money is a top concern for the company, and this shows in the way benefits have been taken away from employees, and they are told to try and "do more with less". review_title: The SSM Acquisition Soured The Taste
job_title: IT Manager in Madison, WI
pros: Dean has a majority market share in Dane and the surrounding counties as a Health Insurance Provider.  This means that there is no immediate concern of this company moving as it's firmly rooted here in Madison.  The quality of employees is, like most companies, a mixed bag, but I find that many people at Dean Health Plan (DHP) take pride in their work and are motivated by doing it well.  I still keep in contact with many former co-workers and frankly that's the most bittersweet aspect of no longer working there.
cons:
Prior to the SSM acquisition of Dean Health System (DHS) and Dean Health Plan, DHP was run for most intents and purposes as it's own autonomous company.  There were tie-ins with DHS and SSM, but corporate policy was dictated internally and the company was run as an Insurance Company.

After SSM finalized the purchase of the Dean system, a large-scale integration effort was performed.  While there are many similarities between a hospital chain and a Health clinic chain, neither of those industries has much business cross-over with Health Insurance.  Sure, all systems talk with one another, but providing care to a patient and resolving a claim filed by that patient are two entirely different processes and workflows.  After the acquisition, DHP was no longer able to operate as an autonomous company, nor even a seperate business entity.  Frankly policies that only had merit within a Health Care system found there way into the Insurance Company as well even though the provided no benefit.

Since the acquisition, mandatory flu shots has been put in place (this makes sense in clinics and hospitals, but the insurance company that rarely sees clients in person??).  Average Annual Raises have significantly decreased (or outright frozen in certain cases), and capital budgetary items have been dramatically cut.

Just not the same place it was before the acquisition and this was frankly my main reason for leaving.

job_title: Director in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Company tries hard to balance national economy and single employee needs.

review_title: High Turnover & Selective on who is promoted
job_title: Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great working environment, benefit, and pension plan.
cons: The company doesn't invest in current employees, and only selected few are given opportunities to advance internally. Morale is low because external applicants are given the opportunity for key positions over current high-performing employees. When internal applicants apply for key positions, they are not given the courtesy of an interview, only a letter of "You do not meet/qualify." job_title: Pre-Services Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Department coworkers and other employees within the facility are very friendly and courteous.  The work is very interesting and challenging.  Due to sheer volume of accounts processed and the complexity of everyday operations you receive little effective direct support and training from Department Leads and Supervisors, but on the flip side there is a high degree of autonomy and flexibility in how you complete your work and when you take your rest and lunch breaks.  Although there is a formal annual employee performance evaluation process, all non-probationary employees received the exact same 2% raise in 2016.  This would be great if you are a sub-standard performer, but a bit deflating if you happen to be a high-energy top achiever.  Pay and benefits are below industry average but the PTO policy has, at least historically, been very flexible.
cons: From my own personal experience it appears to be virtually impossible to be internally promoted at SSM if you hire into a large, high-turnover department such as Pre-Service.  Human Resources uses Taleo Recruiting software for initial screening of candidates and each manager has a direct link to it through the HR website.  Several veteran employees within the department believe that managers have the ability to block individuals or even specific groups of employees from being given consideration for positions outside of the department, and have actually done so in the past.  If this is indeed true, and managers are presently engaging in this egregious activity, it would go a long way toward explaining my own lack of success.  Even if you are fortunate enough to receive a rare contact from a “Talent Acquisition Specialist” the best that you seem to get is a very pleasant person reading questions to you off of an obvious script that was indexed against your electronic application, as though you were a non-SSM applicant being considered for new hire.  What you have accomplished professionally or academically, or how reliable and helpful you have readily and steadily been to your Supervisor and fellow coworkers, apparently bears little real value.  Sadly, it has ultimately been much easier for many of my now former co-workers to gain advancement by leaving SSM for one of the competitors, which of course contributes to the high-turnover ratio.  This particular factor is just one of several operational factors that have resulted in extremely low overall employee morale within the department.  And from an organization that continually promotes and stresses moral values and individual ethical obligations to its employees this, at the very least questionable, practice is more than a wee bit contradictory.

Also, their health insurance doesn't cover birth control unless it's coded/billed EXACTLY right. 
You are required to work minor holidays that they don't pay you for and if you call in they schedule you for the next holiday. The major holidays you are required to work you still probably won't get holiday pay for. Have fun spending New Year's Eve at the hospital for base pay.

cons:
It's been a rough ride since being acquired by SSM. Dean was a physician owed company so you worked with the owners every day. They truly cared about the employees and treated them fairly.

SSM is very corporate and it's about the bottom line. The people who are losing are the employees.

Being the largest (and one of few) clinic systems they own it is pretty obvious their thing is hospitals and they are not grasping clinics operate differently. 

They are also clueless about HMO markets.

SSM is not family friendly (although they like to tell you they are)
Cost of benefits to employees with families has gone up A LOT since SSM took over. People with families have to pay a higher percentage of their health insurance costs. Family is 25%, employee +1 is 20%,  single is 15%. If your spouses employer offers insurance then you get to pay and extra $150/ mo. This was an increase of $210/ mo for employees with families (before the usual yearly increase). Health care costs went down for singles.
(The plan coverage is also not as good as it used to be)

Non planned absences went down from 7 days in a rolling 12 month period to 3 days.

But they give you $7000 to adopt a child (you then just won't be able to afford your insurance)

review_title: Competent and thorough nurses with high expectactions from management

cons: Sometimes managment seems to keep wanting more and more of staff nurses, and expectations can become unrealistic. job_title: Staff RN in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Beautiful hospital. Computer work stations outside and inside every patient room. Supplies close to patients rooms. Carpeted hallways help joints after long hours.
cons:
Very cliquish. Many nurses were from the Old St Joe in Kirkwood. Found that many of our coworkers were the bosses friends. After the economy tanked, nurses were delegated to cleaning rooms and taking trash and laundry from patients rooms. (Yes, degreed nurses) 
Cost cutting also affected dietary. They may drop off a lunch tray, but often, it was still there after dinner, because nurses and the occasional aide were too busy to get them removed from rooms. Nurses making over $28/hour were obviously phased out- new nurses through the Futures Program were filling positions. ($20-$21 an hour). Nurse A was out of school 6 months, when she began training Nurse B, a new grad. I had 7 years as a CSN, and Charge RN, and carefully, (sweetly, encouragingly) asked why A was training B, when I was seasoned. I got the answer that Nurse A had "excellent organizational skills." This meant that Nurse A got all of her computer charting done on time, and never stayed later than 7:30 catching up on charting. Yes, the younger ones DO have that computer thing down- but so do I. I just nursed my patients better. I asked Nurse A to watch my patients while I took a restroom break. I came back to report by Nurse A that Patient 2A had needed to use the BR. She unhooked his IV antibiotics, and he was probably ready to be hooked back up. I went in to find an open line, and the patients IV backed up. No flush, no clamp-off, no cap on the IV line. I sweetly explained to her that she needed to cap, etc. She said, Why? I do that all of the time!" I taught her, (patiently) that she was opening the patient up to infection, and another IV stick due to the improper handling of that line, and that the tubing, antibiotics, and fluids would all need to be replaced. I have no idea if she learned anything- but I'm guessing that she taught her new grads the wrong way too. I left not long after for surgery, and I saw on Facebook that that new nurse is now traveling. I relinquished my job so my floor wouldn't suffer staffing number issues, but its been over a year now, and I cant get back into SSM to save my life. I'm not young, but I'm not old either. I'm not even top of the pay scale, having only been a nurse for 7 years.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO

Years of experience is the only thing that matters; there is no balance. And not just regarding promotions, the number of years of experience you have will be in direct relation to how you are treated.

The amount of disorganization and mismanagement for a company this big is, quite frankly, alarming. 

A bunch of excel sheets, a shared drive (NOT a document management system), and a completely unhelpful "standard operating procedures" binder comprise the legal department of SSM.

I did not get an apology.  At times I felt upper management was too quick to jump on things and several of these incidences happened to me. cons: This company, since merging with SSM continues to devalue and disrespect their employees. Employees are leaving in flocks and the employees left behind assume the work load of three to four people. Even worse, there is no gratitude or respect for the work they are doing. There is a constant change in leadership, who all come in with a new vision, who all continue to roll out projects at an unmanageable pace with very ridiculous timelines and none of these said leaders sitting in their offices actually have to do the work, so are unaffected and turn a deaf ear to those sounding the alarms. The employees would like to do a good, quality job but no longer have the tools to do so. Little perks like working off-site or wearing jeans or providing some munchies for an occasion have all vanished. The culture is chaotic and negative with employee morale at its lowest. The pay is meager, especially in places with a higher cost of living.  The pay increases or salaries have not kept up.  Whereas pay used to be based on your work effort and quality it is now equal and minimal for all employees even further reducing the drive of anyone to put a passionate, quality work effort into their projects.  Yet the most disgraceful change in environment is that the employees who used to be respected for their expertise, skills and knowledge are now thought of robots with no opinion and are not listened to for exactly the points on their resume they were hired for.  The chiefs in this company, although not experts in most areas, think they know best and do not listen to those who are below them.

The leadership drive in their super expensive, super fancy cars, while workers are applying for health assistance.  We are a healthcare company that owns our own health insurance, and other companies that use our health insurance (DHP) get WAY better rates than we do.  Odd...  Management doesn't staff enough, say yes to as many projects as they can and can look away because they aren't the ones working nights and weekends to meet deadlines.  The last thing people had a bit of sanity about was their ability to work from home and enjoy that option, which has since been taken away to, get this, "improve culture".  Ha!  You are taken a privilege away but not giving anything back - how does that improve culture?  Our company did a massive market analysis a while back of what employees should really be paid, since it was clear we weren't stacking up with our competitors and losing peole right and left... so they did the analysis, and told us where we "should" fall based on their research, but then we still have not been put into that pay.  That doesn't make any sense right?  Why even do it if you can't stand behind paying us what you yourself say we should be getting paid.  Employees are leaving left and right and they are just allowing this, not doing anything to improve our lives at this job.  They care about making their big salaries which are vastly different than ours.  And then just as fast as we have leadership come in, they too leave to bigger and better opportunities.

I tried to transfer to their Intergrated Health Division (the higher paying jobs with little or no IT experience needed), and your current department manager has the ability to block your transfer (but HR or other department managers will not tell you that your department manager blocked your transfer, instead they will state that you were not chosen...sometimes HR or the department that you want to transfer into wont even let you know that you were not chosen for the position...I was fortunate enough to find out from a former employee/department manager who told me that he wanted to hire me, but my department manager stated that 'there is a critical need in her department, therefore she couldn't let me transfer)....it's full of crap....hence, I am stuck in a department that I will either have to quit or pray that the department manager will quit......

Too much brown nosing.......in my department, I have seen employees in our department manager's office for half of their shift.....and call off or come in late without being written up for it.............

All the male workers (and I am a male employee) are either in IT, at the top of the company, or on the very bottom (security officers, janitors, etc...).....in my department, I am the only male out of 55 people........I want out!!!!!...I am stuck in a department that has high turnover......all the new hires will quit once they find out that working holidays, sometimes being asked (and when I say asked they are saying 'stay or if you make my job harder, then I will make it harder on you later on...) to cover shifts or stay over....it's bs.....

Pay raises suck.......

Matching 401(k) is very low.......make sure you vote to keep the current social security system in the US......if you stay with this company

job_title: RN Case Manager in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: Office staff were really nice
cons:
The office was run from another branch in St Louis. Scheduling was done from St. Louis, therefore the scheduling personnel sometimes didn't have a full picture of things going on in the OKC branch. For example, if I were asked to go into the office to have a meeting, the St. Louis scheduling team didn't know this and continued to schedule a full day. They also had no idea the areas in which a nurse worked so would schedule patients all over the map and expect you to be able to see a full day. The expectations were unrealistic. The point system for productivity was unrealistic. 2 points for admits, with McKesson charting. The nurse was responsible for the entire admission, the F2F, the 485 and running the admit though SHP and completing any changes, which took days. On call working weekends was every other weekend and at times, would have 4 admits on a Saturday and 3-4 on a Sunday. This was expected to be an 8 hour day on top of driving all around. They never looked at your actual schedule for realistic hours. Then, questioned any overtime. There was one team lead that was an advocate and do what she could to assist the nurses, but upper management didn't allow much wiggle room. If you didn't have the 6 points needed for a full day, they would automatically assign extra things to you without considering mileage. Mileage was not looked at at all. Once was required to go to a 2 hour meeting and also still see 6 points while driving over 100 miles that day. Meetings in office not considered in work day at all. Most of the other staff were miserable as well but voiced that they loved their patients and had been there so long they didn't want to leave. Management changed within last 2 years and a lot of things went down hill.  Staff would try to voice complaints during different meetings and were told to take it to management. 
I constantly was home charting after working 8 hours, never ending job.  
Overall, worst job experience.
